Induction Therapy.goal: The goal is to rapidly clear leukemia cells (blasts) from the blood and bone marrow to achieve Complete Remission (CR) and restore normal blood cell production.

drugs.name: Daunorubicin or Idarubicin
drugs.dose: 60 mg/m²/day over 5-15 min or 12 mg/m²/day over 10-15 min
drugs.note: Check cardiac function before starting, Use central venous line (PICC/CVC) for Idarubicin / Daunorubicin - avoid peripheral veins.

NursesInfo: Verify Cardiac Baseline: Confirm documented Echo or MUGA scan shows EF ≥ 50% prior to Idarubicin administration.
Monitor Cytarabine Toxicity: Assess for Cytarabine-induced skin rash and provide prophylactic steroid eye drops for conjunctivitis.
Track TLS Risk: Monitor strict I/O and daily weights to identify early signs of Tumor Lysis Syndrome.
Assess Mucosal Integrity: Perform daily oral assessments for mucositis and ensure using Mucositis formula if required.
Monitor Hematologic Recovery: Track ANC and platelets daily; implement strict neutropenic precautions during the expected nadir.

drugs.name: Filgrastim (G-CSF)
drugs.note: Continue until ANC >1000 in two consecutive days

NursesInfo: Verify Cardiac Baseline: Ensure baseline EF ≥ 50% is documented prior to Idarubicin administration.
Monitor Fludarabine Neurotoxicity: Assess for changes in mental status or peripheral neuropathy related to Fludarabine.
Track Prolonged Neutropenia: Prepare for extended myelosuppression; implement strict infection control and growth factor support.
Confirm TLS Prophylaxis: Monitor for Tumor Lysis Syndrome; ensure adequate hydration and Allopurinol/Rasburicase are active.
Assess Line Integrity: Verify brisk blood return prior to Idarubicin infusion to mitigate high extravasation risk.
Monitor Cerebellar Function: Perform regular neuro checks to identify Cytarabine-induced ataxia or nystagmus.
Assess Pulmonary Status: Monitor for dyspnea or cough as Fludarabine and Ara-C can rarely cause pulmonary toxicity.
Track Neutropenic Nadir: Monitor for severe infection risk due to high-dose synergistic myelosuppression.
Manage Ocular Care: Ensure the patient uses prophylactic saline or steroid eye drops throughout the Ara-C infusion.
Monitor Renal Function: Track creatinine levels to ensure appropriate clearance of Fludarabine metabolites.

Consolidation Therapy.goal: The goal is to eliminate any Minimal Residual Disease (MRD)—undetectable leukemia cells—to prevent relapse and maintain long-term remission.

NursesInfo: Indication: AML in remission in patients who are under 60 years of age.
Side effects: "Cytarabine syndrome", "Tumour lysis syndrome", Cytarabine induced neurotoxicity, Nausea and Vomiting
Perform Neuro Checks: Assess cerebellar function (handwriting, gait, finger-to-nose) before every dose to detect Ara-C induced ataxia.
Administer Ocular Prophylaxis: Ensure corticosteroid eye drops are administered 2 hours prior to initial dose Cytarabine and then every 6 hours to prevent chemical conjunctivitis.
Monitor for Cytarabine Syndrome: Track for fever, myalgia, bone pain, and rash occurring typically 6–12 hours after administration.
Track Neutropenic Nadir: Monitor CBC daily; implement strict infection control due to expected profound myelosuppression.
Maintain Skin Integrity: Assess for Ara-C induced hand-foot syndrome or maculopapular rash and provide topical emollients as needed.

Maintenance Therapy.goal: The goal is to provide prolonged, low-intensity therapy to suppress any remaining leukemia cells and reduce the risk of recurrence, especially in patients ineligible for stem cell transplant.

NursesInfo: Premediication Ondansetron oral
Nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea are common.
Can also be administered as IV

Induction Phase.goal: The goal is to quickly eradicate lymphoid blasts to reach Complete Remission (CR) and provide CNS prophylaxis to prevent leukemia from spreading to the brain or spinal cord.

drugs.name: Mesna
drugs.note: Start 5 minutes after finish of Ondansetron

drugs.name: Cyclophosphamide
drugs.note: Start 5 minutes after start of Mesna

drugs.name: Vincristine
drugs.note: Make sure patient has bowel motion on the day of administration.

drugs.name: Filgrastim (GCSF)
drugs.note: Until ANC >1000 in two consecutive days

NursesInfo: Verify Cardiac Baseline: Confirm a documented Echo or MUGA scan within 6 months shows EF ≥ 50% prior to Cyclophosphamide administration.
Confirm Mesna Timing: Ensure Mesna infusion is synchronized correctly with Cyclophosphamide to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis.
Monitor Steroid Impact: Check blood glucose levels frequently due to the high-dose Dexamethasone component.
Audit CNS Prophylaxis: Ensure Intrathecal (IT) chemotherapy is synchronized with the systemic window as per the roadmap.
Assess Port Patency: Perform a brisk blood return check on the CVAD immediately before hanging vesicants or high-volume infusions.

drugs.name: Prednisolone 1%
drugs.note: Start 2 hours before the first dose Cytarabine.

drugs.name: Calcium folinate
drugs.note: Start 36 hours AFTER the START of second MTX

drugs.name: Bactrim
drugs.note: Hold While MTX and until clearence

drugs.name: Fluconazole
drugs.note: Hold if any other Antifungal active

drugs.name: Filgrastim
drugs.note: Continue until ANC >1000 in 2 consecutive days

NursesInfo: Validate Urine Alkalinization: Confirm urine pH is > 7.0 prior to starting High-Dose Methotrexate to prevent renal precipitation.
Monitor Neurotoxicity: Perform handwriting and gait assessments to screen for Cytarabine-induced cerebellar toxicity.
Execute Leucovorin Rescue: Ensure Leucovorin is administered exactly at the scheduled intervals until Methotrexate levels are safe.
Monitor Renal Clearance: Track serum creatinine and maintain aggressive hydration (>100 mL/hr) during Methotrexate infusion.
Audit CNS Prophylaxis: Coordinate timing for Intrathecal (IT) Methotrexate and or Cytarabine as specified for Cycle B.
Monitor MTX Clearance: Check urine pH every void after Sodium Bicarbonate start and daily after MTX start until level < 0.1 μmol/L.
Audit MTX Levels: Draw first MTX level 1 hour after second dose completion, then every 24 hours until level < 0.1 μmol/L.

drugs.name: Vincristine
drugs.note: Give only if patient has bowel motion on the day.

drugs.name: Filgrastim (GCSF)
drugs.note: Continue until ANC >1000 in two consecutive days.

NursesInfo: Verify Cardiac Baseline: Confirm a documented Echo or MUGA scan within 6 months shows EF ≥ 50% prior to Cyclophosphamide administration.

Validate Dose Reductions: Cross-check that the "Mini" doses (usually 50% reduction of Cyclophosphamide and Dexamethasone, and omitting Anthracyclines) match the age-adjusted or renal-adjusted parameters in the MAR.
Confirm TLS Prophylaxis: Verify that Allopurinol is started and the patient has achieved an aggressive fluid intake/output balance (typically >100 mL/hr to prevent Tumor Lysis Syndrome.
Audit CNS Prophylaxis Timing: Ensure the scheduled Intrathecal (IT) chemotherapy (Methotrexate and/or Cytarabine) is synchronized with the systemic Cycle A window as per the protocol roadmap.
Assess Port/Line Patency: Perform a brisk blood return check on the Central Venous Access Device (PICC) immediately before hanging vesicants or high-volume infusions to mitigate extravasation risk.

drugs.name: Methotrexate
drugs.note: Intrathecal, may combine with Cytarabine and Hydrocortisone

drugs.name: Calcium Folinate
drugs.note: Start 12 hours AFTER finish of MTX, then Q6H. Continue until MTX level <0.1

drugs.name: Cytarabine
drugs.note: Start 24 hours AFTER finish of MTX, then Q12H (4 doses)

drugs.name: Methotrexate
drugs.note: Intrathecal, may combine with Cytarabine and Hydrocortisone

drugs.name: Filgrastim (GCSF)
drugs.note: Continue until ANC >1000 two consecutive days

NursesInfo: Validate Dose Reductions: Cross-check that doses match the age-adjusted or renal-adjusted parameters (typically 50% reduction).
Verify Anthracycline Omission: Confirm that anthracyclines are omitted as per the "mini" protocol variation.
Monitor Urine pH: Ensure urine pH remains > 7.0 for Methotrexate clearance despite the reduced dosage.
Assess Myelosuppression: Monitor for prolonged cytopenias which may occur even with dose-reduced chemotherapy.
Confirm Eye Care: Administer steroid eye drops as ordered to mitigate Cytarabine-related chemical conjunctivitis.
Monitor MTX Clearance: Check urine pH every void after Sodium Bicarbonate start and daily after MTX start until level < 0.1 μmol/L.
Audit MTX Levels: Draw first MTX level 1 hour after second dose completion, then every 24 hours until level < 0.1 μmol/L.

drugs.name: S.Lipase, S. Amylase, S. Fibrinogen
drugs.note: With routine labs, until MTX clearance

drugs.name: Vincristine
drugs.note: Maximum dose 2mg. Check bowel motion before giving dose

drugs.name: Methotrexate
drugs.note: Start after urine pH >8, Check urine pH daily

drugs.name: Calcium folinate
drugs.note: 36 hours AFTER START of MTX. Continue until MTX clearance.

NursesInfo: Asparaginase Monitoring: Monitor fibrinogen and amylase/lipase levels. Inspect for DVT (swelling/redness) as Asparaginase significantly increases clot risk.
Vincristine Safety: Confirm bowel movements daily to assess for ileus
Intrathecal Care: Post-lumbar puncture, ensure the patient remains flat for 30–60 minutes to prevent spinal headache

Chronic Phase.goal: To achieve Major Molecular Response (MMR) and maintain a normal life expectancy by managing the leukemia as a stable, long-term condition.

drugs.name: Hydroxyurea
drugs.note: Only if WBC >100k; stop once TKI starts

drugs.name: Imatinib
drugs.note: Take with a large glass of water and a meal

NursesInfo: Monitor for periorbital edema
Assess for muscle cramps; consider calcium/magnesium supplements
Verify patient is not taking St. John's Wort or systemic steroids
Monitor CBC every 2 weeks for Grade 3/4 neutropenia

drugs.name: Dasatinib
drugs.note: May take with or without food

NursesInfo: Screen for new-onset dry cough or shortness of breath (Pleural Effusion risk)
Strict Contraindication: Do not take with PPIs (Omeprazole, etc.); use antacids 2hrs apart
Baseline EKG required to monitor QTc interval
Instruct patient to report any unusual bruising or bleeding immediately
Strict "Fast State": No food 2 hours before and 1 hour after dose
Monitor Lipase and Amylase levels every 3 months
Assess for peripheral arterial occlusive disease (leg pain when walking)
Schedule qPCR testing exactly every 3 months to track MMR/DMR status
Rotate injection sites (thigh, abdomen, or upper arm)
Monitor for severe hyperglycemia (check blood glucose regularly)
Monitor for sever thrombocytopenia
Transition to 7-day maintenance once Hematologic Response is achieved
Mandatory qPCR testing every 4 weeks for the first 6 months
Flag "Loss of MMR" if  BCR::ABL1 rises >0.1%
Educate patient on TKI Withdrawal Syndrome (acute joint/muscle pain)
Counsel patient that restarting TKI within 4 weeks of MMR loss is 95% successful

Blast Phase.goal: The goal is to rapidly restore the disease to a second Chronic Phase and stabilize the patient to serve as a bridge to a life-saving Bone Marrow Transplant.

NursesInfo: High risk of Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS); monitor Uric Acid, K+, and Phosphorus every 8–12 hours.
Perform daily skin assessments for "Ara-C Rash" or palmoplantar erythrodysesthesia.
Dasatinib specific: Monitor for pleural effusion (assess for dry cough and decreased breath sounds).
Maintain strict neutropenic precautions and monitor for febrile neutropenia.

drugs.name: Filgrastim (GCSF)
drugs.note: Continue until ANC >1000 in 2 consecutive days

NursesInfo: Neuro-checks every 8 hours required for High-Dose Cytarabine (assess for cerebellar ataxia/nystagmus).
Corticosteroid eye drops (e.g., Prednisolone) required Q6H to prevent chemical conjunctivitis.
Idarubicin may cause red-colored urine (not hematuria); counsel the patient.
Fludarabine is highly immunosuppressive; monitor for opportunistic infections.

drugs.name: Cyclophosphamide
drugs.note: Use with Mesna for bladder protection

drugs.name: Vincristine
drugs.note: Check for bowel movement before administration

NursesInfo: Ponatinib specific: High risk for Arterial Occlusive Events (AOE); monitor for limb pain or coldness.
Monitor BP and cardiovascular status daily due to Ponatinib's risk profile.
"Vincristine is for IV use ONLY": Fatal if given by any other route (especially intrathecal).
Assess for Mesna compliance; encourage fluid intake to prevent hemorrhagic cystitis
Patient must remain flat (supine) for at least 1–2 hours post-procedure to prevent spinal headache.
Monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure (severe headache, vomiting).

First-Line Therapy (Treatment-Naïve).goal: To achieve a long-term remission and reach uMRD (Undetectable Minimal Residual Disease) so treatment can be stopped.

NursesInfo: Monitor for new-onset atrial fibrillation (check pulse regularly)
Assess for minor bruising or bleeding (common with BTK inhibitors)
Monitor blood pressure; hypertension is a known long-term side effect

drugs.name: Obinutuzumab
drugs.note: Split dose, Pre-medication for infusion reactions

drugs.name: Venetoclax
drugs.note: 5-week Ramp-Up: 20 mg x 7 days, then 50 mg, 100 mg, 200 mg, to 400 mg

drugs.name: Venetoclax
drugs.note: 5-week Ramp-Up: 20 mg x 7 days, then 50 mg, 100 mg, 200 mg, to 400 mg

drugs.name: Venetoclax
drugs.note: 5-week Ramp-Up: 20 mg x 7 days, then 50 mg, 100 mg, 200 mg, to 400 mg

drugs.name: Venetoclax
drugs.note: 5-week Ramp-Up: 20 mg x 7 days, then 50 mg, 100 mg, 200 mg, to 400 mg

NursesInfo: Each cycle is 28 days
Monitor for Tumor Lysis Syndrome (TLS) during the 5-week ramp-up
Ensure the patient is aggressively hydrated (2L/day) during ramp-up
Administer allopurinol as prescribed for uric acid management

Second-Line / Relapsed Therapy.goal: To bypass resistance (e.g., if they failed a BTKi, move to a BCL2i) and restore quality of life.

NursesInfo: Monitor for neutropenia; G-CSF support may be needed
Check for "Rituximab Infusion Reaction" during the first hour of IV
Verify that the patient is not on strong CYP3A4 inhibitors (e.g., Grapefruit juice)

drugs.name: Vincristine
drugs.note: After Doxorubicin; Make sure bowel movement today before administer.

drugs.name: Prednisolone
drugs.note: ONCE a day on days 1 to 5. Take in the morning with food. Dose for day 1 should be taken 60 minutes before Rituximab infusion.

NursesInfo: Monitor for "Red Devil" (Doxorubicin) cardiac toxicity
Assess for Vincristine-induced neuropathy (numbness in fingers/toes)

Induction Phase.goal: To prevent fatal hemorrhage and force the immature "promyelocyte" blasts to mature into healthy white blood cells.

drugs.name: Prednisolone
drugs.note: Round to nearest 5 mg, Taper off after 28 days.

drugs.name: Arsenic Tri Oxide (ATO)
drugs.note: Keep Mg >2 and K >4, Give premedication (Mg +/- K) IV before ATO

NursesInfo: High Alert: Monitor for Differentiation Syndrome (fever, weight gain, dyspnea); report to MD immediately.
Monitor daily Fibrinogen and PT/INR; keep Fibrinogen >1.5 with cryoprecipitate.
Arsenic Monitoring: Daily EKG is mandatory to check for QTc prolongation, inform physician if QTc >500 ms
Strictly avoid lumbar punctures or invasive procedures during the first 2 weeks due to bleeding risk.

Consolidation.goal: To eliminate any "Minimal Residual Disease" (MRD) and ensure the PML::RARA gene is no longer detectable.

drugs.name: Tretinoin (ATRA)
drugs.note: Given during the first 2 weeks of each ATO cycle

drugs.name: Arsenic Tr Oxide (ATO)
drugs.note: cycles total (4 weeks on / 4 weeks off)

NursesInfo: Assess for peripheral neuropathy (numbness/tingling) caused by cumulative Arsenic exposure.
Monitor Liver Function Tests (ALT/AST) weekly; Arsenic can cause reversible hepatotoxicity.
Verify "Molecular Remission" via PCR testing at the end of the final cycle.
